title: Mads Pedersen clinches Denmark's first men's world championship road race title under horrid Yorkshire skies
text:
Come to Yorkshire, they said. Well they came in their thousands for the finale of the Road World Championships and, despite the appalling conditions that led to the men’s road race being rerouted, remained in buoyant mood throughout a very soggy day in North Yorkshire.

Almost 200 riders from 42 nations set out from Leeds on Sunday morning. Just 46 finished. There was though only one that took home the coveted rainbow jersey: Mads Pedersen, the 23-year-old from Denmark. Matteo Trentin, of Italy was runner-up with Swiss rider Stefan Küng taking the bronze.

“I think it’s unbelievable for the nation, we’ve finally got the jersey,” Pedersen said after becoming the first Dane to win the men's title.

“You had to be focused all day and stay in the front all the time. But it’s one of the last races of the season, so it’s all about keeping that focus for 6½ hours and don’t have any bad luck and hope for the best.

“This is every rider’s dream to wear this jersey. It’s unbelievable.”

Heavy overnight downpours forced race organisers to take out 23.5km out of what had been scheduled to be the longest men’s road race in the history of the championships while two key climbs – Buttertubs Pass and Grinton Moor – were removed. Few would claim the adjustments made it any easier. Indeed, it turned out to be one of the most brutish world championship road races in recent memory.
